Award.AwardTitle: Imaging Cellulose - Carbohydrate Binding Module Interactions With Nanometer Resolution Using Single Molecule Flourescence Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1206908 PI: Smith, Steve ORG: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology

Title: Imaging Cellulose - Carbohydrate Binding Module Interactions with Nanometer Resolution Using Single Molecule Fluorescence Methods

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Cellulose, one of the most abundant biopolymers on earth, is a naturally occurring nanomaterial. It is the primary component of plant cell walls and the feedstock for valuable products derived from biomass sugars, such as liquid and gaseous fuels. Most of what is known about the chemical structure of biomass comes from analysis of the products generated during its decomposition via batch methods. These approaches necessarily lose the spatial correlations between the biomolecules that drive biomass degradation and the chemical-spatial structure of the feedstock, that is, the plant cell wall and its primary constituents, cellulose, hemi-cellulose, and lignin. This project will focus on exploiting single molecule, super-resolution imaging methods to reveal important facets of cellulose-carbohydrate binding module (CBM) interactions that are lost in the ensemble averaging of batch analyses. CBMs play a critical role in the action of a large family of cellulase enzymes, locating and positioning the catalytic components on their target substrates. This project will utilize single molecule fluorescence methods to reveal molecular level details of the interaction of families of CBMs, derived from microbial, bacterial, and cellulosomal sources, with cellulose substrates. The binding characteristics of single CBMs, including specificity, orientation, motility, and binding persistence will be studied using CBMs tagged with fluorescent proteins (FPs), including photo-activated FPs, to extract orientation and positional information at the single molecule level. Sequential imaging of sparse subsets of single molecules with high resolution imaging approaching the 5nm level will be used to study these processes and the spatio-chemical structure of biomass.

BROADER IMPACTS: This project aims to provide detailed knowledge of cellulose-carbohydrate binding module interactions, thus building a biophysical knowledge of the molecular processes responsible for the breakdown of cellulose to simple sugars, knowledge critical to enabling new biotechnologies, which could accelerate conventional bioprocessing. Such knowledge could, for instance, aid in selecting new enzymes or designing enzymatic bioprocessing systems. This work thus leverages the significant efforts made by the State of South Dakota towards the utilization of biomass in the production of biofuels and other biomass-derived products, and investments made toward stimulating this industry. The proposed work will enrich graduate and undergraduate education in South Dakota by enabling collaborative research opportunities and interdisciplinary training for scientists and engineers in the region. SDSM&T also maintains a permanent Native American outreach program, with established and well-organized outreach programs such as SD GEAR UP, aimed at increasing the number of Native American high-school students continuing on to college. On-going aspects of this project will be incorporated into the educational portions of this program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OVERVIEW: Cellulose is often referred to as the most abundant biopolymer on earth, but expensive enzymes are required to break cellulose down from its native form in the plant cell wall (e.g. wood) to a useable bio-polymer that can be further processed to produce valuable bio-products such as ethanol and bio-degradable materials for buildings, packaging and bio-medical applications. The overarching scientific goal of NSF project DMR-1206908 was to explore advanced single molecule imaging methods to achieve a molecular level understanding of the action of a class of carbohydrate-specific binding proteins known as Carbohydrate Binding Modules (CBMs), and specifically their interaction with plant cell wall materials, primarily elementary bundles of crystalline cellulose known as nano-fibrils or micro-fibril bundles. These CBMs are a functional component of all cellulose degrading enzymes, and thus play a critical role in biomass utilization for energy and high value bio-products. This project provided molecular scale details of the structure of cellulose on the nanometer scale, and insights into how enzymatic degradation of cellulose to it’s elemental components for deployment in high value bio-products may be improved.

Intellectual merit: By imaging carbohydrate binding modules (CBMs), a key component of all cellulase enzymes, and their interaction with cellulose substrates, the specificity of their corresponding enzyme or enzyme complex can be understood in terms of the structure of the enzyme and the target. Understanding how the spatial variation in the CBM binding aides in inferring how variations in CBM action and the degree of crystallinity on the nanoscale may affect efficiency of enzymatic hydrolysis. By imaging the motility of synergistic enzymes using high-speed atomic force microscopy (AFM), this validates the current industrial practice of using enzymatic cocktails, and aides in proposing improvements in such enzyme mixtures. The new tools, such as correlated fluorescence / AFM and multi-photon microscopy developed for this project have found applications in other areas, including studies of the genetic origins of plant adaptation to harsh conditions and biophysical mechanisms of immune cell response.

Broader Impact: The research outcomes and findings provide knowledge that could lead to advances in the application of bio-renewable materials energy production. By studying how cellulase enzymes and their components work to break-down cellulose to simple sugars, and discerning the nanoscale structure of cellulose nano-fibrils, new technologies which take advantage of this knowledge may be developed, potentially leading to lower cost bio-fuels, biodegradable building and packaging mateirials, and immune system-friendly drug delievery vehicles, sutures and implants. In terms of training and workforce development, students, postdocs and faculty from SDSMT have been trained in the areas of superresolution and scanning probe microscopy, and engaged in collaborative research with researchers at multiple institutes across the State of South Dakota and the Nation.

The participants on this project participated in organized outreach activites, including SDSMTs program for Native American pre-college students known as GEARUP and the (Graduate) Women in Science and Engineering programs (WISE and GWISE). The Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduates Program (GEARUP), whose mission is to increase the number of American Indian students that achieve success in higher education, focusing on matriculation and retention from 8th-to-9th grade and 12th grade-to-college. SDSMT maintains an active WISE (Women In Science and Engineering) center with dedicated staff and reserved study and lounge spaces within SDSMT’s “Student Success” resource center. The center’s goals are to assist female students in all aspects of student success, and to sponsor Industry / alumni speaker talks, wellness workshops, networking and outreach events, social events and a weekly STEMinist Study Hall. Project participants organized a nanoscience booth in the in 2017 WISE public outreach science and engineering fair for area middle school girls. Graduate students interacted with more than 800 middle school girls by demonstrating live cell imaging and scale models of imaged obtained in during the project.

Summary: Through NSF grant DMR-1206908, the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology and Michigan State University collaborated on a project to use advanced imaging methods to examine the action of a class of carbohydrate specific binding proteins, carbohydrate binding modules (CMBs) and the structure of the plant cell wall and its crystalline components, primarily cellulose nano-fibrils. Using these methods, CBM-CBM interactions were observed, the variability of CBM binding to nano-fibril surfaces, and its relation to the degree of crystallinity of the elementary nano-fibril was examined. Synergistic action of enzymes on the hydrolysis of cellulose was observed by high speed AFM. The methods developed were applied not only to imaging CBM-nano-cellulose interactions and the structure of nano-cellulose, but also to visualize gene expression in transgenic plants and immune cells response.
